# List of Romanian submissions for the Academy Award for Best International Feature Film

Romania has been submitting films for the Academy Award for Best International Feature Film}} since 1966. The Best Foreign Film award is handed out annually by the United States Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to a feature-length motion picture produced outside the United States that contains primarily non-English dialogue. The Romanian nominee is selected each year by a jury selected by the National Center for Cinematography (Centrul Național al Cinematografiei – CNC).
As of 2025, Romania was nominated only once for the documentary Collective (2020) by Alexander Nanau.
In 2007, 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, the first and only Romanian film to win the Palme d'Or, was not nominated, creating controversy among critics and public opinion about the selection committee unpopular decisions of not nominating critically acclaimed productions. The controversy caused Academy members to public pledge for internal reforms.
Submissions
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has invited the film industries of various countries to submit their best film for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film since 1956. The Foreign Language Film Award Committee oversees the process and reviews all the submitted films. Following this, they vote via secret ballot to determine the five nominees for the award.
Sergiu Nicolaescu's films have been chosen to represent Romania five times since 1969, including once after the Romanian Revolution of 1989.
Among Romania's more notable nominees include: Carnival Scenes, which was produced in 1981 and probably banned by Romania's Communist regime, and eventually released in 1989 after the Romanian Revolution; The Rest Is Silence, the most expensive film in Romanian history.
All films were primarily in Romanian
Below is a list of the films that have been submitted by Romania for review by the Academy for the award since 1966, by year and the respective Academy Awards ceremony. Romania did not enter the competition every year, including a six-year absence from 1977 to 1982.
